p: Outcome measures included clinical course, use of anti-HBV treatment, and progression to chronic infection, using the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD) criteria [ 3, 4]. A protracted–severe course was defined as either >4 weeks of an elevated INR (≥1.5) or total bilirubin >3 mg/dL (or direct >1.5 mg/dL) or clinical evidence of encephalopathy or ascites. The lack of these criteria defined an uncomplicated course. Following AASLD guidelines, indications for anti-HBV treatment included protracted–severe course, and acute liver failure was defined as an elevated INR (≥1.5) with evidence of altered sensorium in a patient without preexisting cirrhosis. HBsAg positivity for at least 6 months after the initial HBsAg-positive result defined chronic HBV infection.
